newsitem.title: GERMANY: German call rates steady after reserve target set.
newsitem.headline: German call rates steady after reserve target set.

text.p: German overnight call rates were little changed on Monday at between 3.08 percent and 3.15 percent after the Bundesbank set a lower-than-expected minimum reserve requirement for February.

The central bank announced earlier that the preliminary minimum reserve requirement for this month had been set at 39.4 billion marks -- lower than expected and below the amount that banks already hold with the central bank.
"The number is not as high as was feared," one trader said.
He and others said they doubt that the Bundesbank will make a significant net add to the money market this week.
Traders said the Bundesbank will not want to let call rates slip to near three percent for fear of igniting speculation about a cut in interest rates.
Some predicted that Lombard borrowing could be heavy this week with pension fund payments making their way through the banking system, causing sharp swings in overnight rates.
As of Friday, banks held 41.7 billion marks with the Bundesbank, up from 41.4 billion marks the day before.
The average for the month so far stood at 40.3 billion marks as of Sunday. Credit institutions borrowed 300 million marks from the Lombard lending facility.
